title: After Another Mass Shooting, Questions Loom About the Role of Parents
abstract: Mothers and fathers of young men accused in shootings, including the 21-year-old charged in the massacre in Highland Park, Ill., have faced scrutiny.
byline: By Mitch Smith, Jack Healy, Frances Robles and Shaila Dewan

title: Inside a Uvalde Classroom: A Taunting Gunman and 78 Minutes of Terror
abstract: A teacher who survived the mass shooting recounts the harrowing attack and desperate wait for a rescue.

multimedia.caption: “I kept waiting for someone to come,” Arnulfo Reyes, a teacher who was wounded in the shooting at Robb Elementary School, said about the delayed police response.

title: More Than 1,000 Protesters at White House Call on Biden to Protect Abortion Rights
abstract: The rally on Saturday, in which some demonstrators risked arrest, reflected activists’ growing frustration with the administration.

title: ‘I Felt Trapped’: Sexual Abuse of Teens in the Military’s J.R.O.T.C. Program
abstract: Former students say military veterans who led J.R.O.T.C. classes in U.S. high schools fashioned themselves as mentors, then used their power to manipulate and abuse.
byline: By Mike Baker, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Ilana Marcus and Mary F. Calvert
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

title: Ukraine’s Demands for More Weapons Clash With U.S. Concerns
abstract: Pulling Ukrainians out of battle to train them could accelerate Russia’s gains, officials say. The Pentagon is also monitoring the levels of its own stockpiles.
byline: By Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

multimedia.caption: Some officials are concerned that pulling too many Ukrainian artillery specialists off the front lines could weaken Ukrainian defenses.

title: Half of G.O.P. Voters Ready to Leave Trump Behind, Poll Finds
abstract: Far from consolidating his support, the former president appears weakened in his party, especially with younger and college-educated Republicans. Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is the most popular alternative.

abstract: The latest, highly contagious variant has driven up hospitalization rates and deepened worries about waning immunity among those vaccinated or boosted months ago.

title: 40 Years Later, Nevada Man Is Charged With Murdering a 5-Year-Old Girl
abstract: Analysis of the DNA in a single strand of rootless hair from a 1982 crime scene helped lead the authorities to arrest Robert J. Lanoue, a 70-year-old registered sex offender, officials said.

multimedia.caption: Last week, after the authorities made an arrest in the 1982 killing of Anne Pham, police officials displayed her picture at Highland Elementary School in Seaside, Calif. She was kidnapped, sexually assaulted and murdered on her way to school.

title: Raskin Brings Expertise on Right-Wing Extremism to Jan. 6 Inquiry
abstract: The Democrat from Maryland has been delving into the rising threat of white nationalism and white supremacy for five years. He will lead the inquiry’s hearing on the subject on Tuesday.
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

multimedia.caption: Representative Jamie Raskin, Democrat of Maryland, will take a leading role in Tuesday’s Jan. 6 committee hearing, which will explore how far-right groups played a pivotal role in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.

abstract: The bureau has long been plagued by health and safety problems, physical and sexual abuse, corruption and turnover in the top management ranks.

abstract: The group, the Republican Accountability PAC, plans to spend at least $10 million to beat candidates who embrace Donald Trump’s false claims about the 2020 election.

title: Gerald W. McEntee, Union Leader With Political Clout, Dies at 87
abstract: He made the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees an electoral force in a time of Republican hostility to organized labor.
org_facet: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees

multimedia.caption: Gerald W. McEntee at a union national conference in Washington in 2007. “He began to use the union’s political power to exact things that in an earlier era the union might have turned to strikes to exact,” a labor historian said.
multimedia.copyright: Rick Gershon/Getty Images

title: Senate Absences Snarl Democrats’ Plans for a Quick Return to Business
abstract: With two Democrats testing positive for the coronavirus and a third convalescing after a fall, the Senate floor is at a standstill, underscoring the fragility of the party’s bare-minimum majority.

title: Hutchinson Testimony Jolts Justice Dept. to Discuss Trump’s Conduct More Openly
abstract: A key witness’s account helped accelerate a shift in the agency’s inquiry: Overt talk about Mr. Trump and his behavior had been rare, except as a motive for the actions of others.

org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

title: Democrats Schedule Votes on Abortion Access, but Lack a Legislative Path
abstract: Democrats in Congress are under pressure to act after the Supreme Court’s decision. But with Republicans and at least one Democrat opposed in the Senate, the measures are all but certain to fail.

title: Texans Warned to Reduce Electricity Use Amid Fear of Rolling Blackouts
abstract: About 50 million people in the United States were under heat warnings or advisories over the weekend. The heat index was forecast to soar past 100 degrees Fahrenheit on Monday in about half of Texas.

title: The Right to Travel in a Post-Roe World
abstract: In a concurring opinion last month, Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh said the Constitution did not allow states to stop women from traveling to get abortions. But the issue is more complicated than that.

multimedia.caption: Demonstrators marched to the home of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh in September. Though some form of a constitutional right to travel is almost uniformly accepted, the Supreme Court has struggled to say exactly where to find it or precisely how to define it.
multimedia.copyright: Tom Brenner for The New York Times

title: F.D.A. to Weigh Over-the-Counter Sale of Contraceptive Pills
